entry.title: Support rounded corner for overlap frame type
entry.content:
With overlap frame type, a header view is put on top of the client view,

overlap in the z-axis.

To round corners, both the top (header view) and the bottom (client

view) views need to be rounded.

The cl contains two changes to handle corner rounding for overlapping

frames:

1. Round the upper corners of the client view.

2. Make HeaderView non-opaque. With the overlapping frames, HeaderView

is painted onto a new layer instead of the non-opaque

ExoShellSurface layer. So the new HeaderView layer also needs to be

non-opaque. Otherwise, the rounded upper corners will come with two

black tips.



Bug: b/320619520

Test: Manual testing to make sure that both ARC and browser windows

behave correctly with rounded corner and frame overlapped enabled.



Change-Id: Ide2803168f59a15404559d42ce56bf0b519d7ce9

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5205110

entry.title: Introduce ServiceWorkerVersion::NeedRouterEvaluate()
entry.content:
This is a refactoring CL.



We'd like to pass the info whether the router evaluation is needed or

not to the renderer. But before doing so, ServiceWorkerVersion should

have a simple boolean method rather than exposing complicated business

logic to the caller side.



This CL introduces ServiceWorkerVersion::NeedRouterEvaluate(), and uses

it in the main resource size.



This doesn't change the existing behavior.



Bug: 1511459

entry.title: Implement support for light-dark() color function
entry.content:
Specification:

https://drafts.csswg.org/css-color-5/#light-dark



Change all -internal-light-dark() instances in UA sheets to

light-dark(). Also use light-dark() for UA-only support for image

values, but guard use with UA mode check.



Coincidentally fixes a bug where -internal-light-dark(GreyText, ...)

was forced, but GreyText was kept as a system color. This is why the

expectation pngs change. Also covered by the new unit test.

entry.title: [WebNN][CrOS]: Support explicit padding for Conv2d/Pool2d
entry.content:
The ResNet graph in WebNN-Samples [1] is differt from original TfLite

model [2], it merged the Pad operator into WebNN Conv2d with explicit

padding, but tflite schema only support SAME or VALID [3] mode, so this

CL inserts a Pad operator before Conv2d to implement the explicit

padding.



[1] https://github.com/webmachinelearning/webnn-samples/tree/master/image_classification

[2] https://storage.googleapis.com/download.tensorflow.org/models/tflite/resnet_v2_50_2018_03_27.zip

[3] https://www.tensorflow.org/mlir/tfl_ops#attributes_11



Bug: 1273291

entry.title: Make "SyncTypesListDisabled" policy support dynamic refresh
entry.content:
This is achieved by more consistently calling the pre-existing

SyncPrefObserver::OnSelectedTypesPrefChange():

Previously, this was called manually by SyncPrefs.

Now, SyncPrefs instead listens to changes to the underlying prefs.

This way, pref changes triggered from outside SyncPrefs itself (such

as by a policy) also get caught.

entry.title: Remove no longer needed raw_ptr rewrite path exclusions
entry.content:
These files were excluded, because raw_ptr and PA depended on them, thus creating a cyclic dependency. Both are now in a standalone library that have their own copy of `base`.



Instead, we need to add manual exclusions in lock_impl.h



This CL removes the exclusions from the clang plugin that enforces

raw_ptr usage, but adds them to the Chromium-side plugin params. This

is to avoid breakage in case new T* show up in these files by the time

the plugin is rolled in.

This is a reland of commit 0f402c037c5a86d11eafe654dd454a6e6cac9a5c

I removed expectation files under

flag-specific/disable-site-isolation-trials that were introduced by a

previous 'rebaseline cl'.



While the tool aims to update expectations accurately, it seems

manual verification is still needed.



Original change's description:

> [URL] Support non-special URLs in Resolve()

>

> Implement correct support for non-special URLs in gurl::Resolve() and

> other functions, which are used on resolving a relative URL on a given

> base URL.

>

> Example:

>

> Prior to this change:

>

> > new URL("path", "git://host/") => throws an invalid URL error

>

> After this change:

>

> > new URL("path", "git://host/") => "git://host/path""

>

> The feature is currently guarded by the flag.

>

> This CL adds several parameterized unit tests to test flag-dependent

> behaviors. Currently flag-independent behaviors are not tested with

> the flag. I will revisit this later.

>

> Though this CL introduces new expectation files for virtual tests,

> there is no regression and the total number of test failures has

> decreased. I use rebaseline cl tool and accept the result as is. It

> seems there are several expectation files across different platforms,

> accumulated over time.

>

entry.title: file_system_provider: add DiversionFileManager
entry.content:
ODFS (OneDrive File System) is a ChromeOS extension for Microsoft's

OneDrive cloud storage, ultimately backed by Microsoft's "Graph API"

(https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/api/resources/onedrive?view=graph-rest-1.0).



ODFS presents a users's Microsoft OneDrive as a volume in ChromeOS'

Files app and other applications can save to and load from that volume.



This includes third-party PWAs (Progressive Web Apps) that use the File

System Access JS API. Chrome's C++ implementation of the FSA API uses a

virtual file system abstraction (SBFS, //storage/browser/file_system)

that isn't specific to the FSP (File System Provider) API or the

FSP-using ODFS. FSP is merely one of many SBFS backends.



To clarify, FSP and FSA are different JS APIs (and are Web standards,

not specific to Chromium, so they are not easily changed). Roughly

speaking, FSP is for file servers (very rare) and FSA is for file

clients (very common). SBFS is yet another API (although a Chromium

private implementation detail, C++ and not JS).



SBFS' POSIX-like model assumes that issuing many small incremental

writes, each appending to the same filename, is efficient (as it is for

local disk). But for cloud-backed storage with one-shot download/upload

APIs, this may translate to a quadratic amount of time and network.



FSA, SBFS and FSP are all "virtual file" related but they are still

different APIs. SBFS' FileStreamWriter has an asynchronous Flush method

but both of the FSA and FSP APIs do not have a flush concept at all. On

the other hand, SBFS's FileStreamWriter does not have an explicit

asynchronous Close method, only a synchronous, infallible destructor.

SBFS assumes that you can read or rename a file immediately after

destroying the writer (and destruction is basically instantaneous) but

for a networked-backed FSP based on a one-shot upload API, closing or

destroying a writer is when the upload actually happens. Uploads are not

instantaneous and they can fail.



There is a fundamental mismatch between the various "virtual file"

models. This commit adds a decorator between the SBFS and FSP boundary

to address quadratic complexity for multiple writes and also insert some

"breathing space" between when a file is closed and when it is moved or

re-opened, giving the fallible upload the time it needs.



In the long term, we might have a "FSP version 2" API that is a better

fit for matching SBFS with Graph-API-like backends. SBFS is also not a

Web standard and so is more malleable (but, unlike FSP, is not limited

to ChromeOS). But changing either (or both) is a separate discussion.



The diversion mechanism is also not specific to FSP backends. It could

also apply to ADP (Android Documents Provider) or MTP (Media Transfer

Protocol) backends. But again, that's out of scope of this commit.



Bug: b:255703917

Bug: b:290285025

Bug: b:320373830

Bug: b:320375163

entry.title: Reuse renderer process when prerendering a COOP page
entry.content:
In the current implementation, when COOP swap occurs in prerender

initial navigation, RenderFrameHostManager swaps the renderer process

twice per SiteInstance and BrowsingInstance recreations:

- The first swap occurs when PrerenderHost is created: new FrameTree is

initialized with new BrowsingInstance / SiteInstance and a new process

will be assigned to it accordingly in its creation.

- The second swap occurs on the COOP swap after receiving the response.



We can avoid these unnecessary recreations by reusing an unlocked

renderer process, unassigned SiteInstance.



As a short term fix, this CL tries to ask a newly created SiteInstance

on COOP swap to reuse the unlocked renderer process that was assigned

upon PreredenrHost creation, via

SiteInstanceImpl::ReuseExistingProcessIfPossible.



Bug: 1519131

Change-Id: I8526e28e27c7b36af6d54ac753611df734b8bb7b

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5232282

Commit-Queue: Taiyo Mizuhashi

entry.title: Revert^3 "[Shortstand] Run WebAppIntegrationTest with Shortstand flag off."
entry.content:
This reverts commit af49c980296612ed1e7256587824487ad19e349d.



Reason for revert: This change has caused all WebAppIntegration tests

to run with unique ash and ~25-30% build time increase on lacros

builder. Since Shorthands feature will not be enabled by default for

another 1 or 2 mile stone, we do not need to set up the tests to run

with unique ash with the feature being off.



Original change's description:

> Revert^2 "[Shortstand] Run WebAppIntegrationTest with Shortstand flag off."

>

> This reverts commit 0b077528c3cf7ac40b43673fafb8364f5f6b17a0.

>

> Reason for revert: I speculatively reverted the original CL. But

> it seems my idea was wrong. The sync_integration_tests failure has

> disappeared even before the reverting CL landed at r1247954.

>

>

> Original change's description:

> > Revert "[Shortstand] Run WebAppIntegrationTest with Shortstand flag off."

> >

> > This reverts commit 247acf8a4fc243d263f3dacd32b47a6e0e83cbcb.

> >

> > Reason for revert: speculatively reverting for crbug.com/1518797 and crbug.com/1518931

> >

> > Bug: 1518797, 1518931

> >

> > Original change's description:

> > > [Shortstand] Run WebAppIntegrationTest with Shortstand flag off.

> > >

> > > This CL makes the WebAppIntegrationTest to always run with Shortstand

> > > flag off even after it is enabled by default. This is because Shortstand

> > > changes the behaviour of shortcuts, which would need significant changes

> > > to WebAppIntegrationTest, and our long term goal is to remove the

> > > shortcut support entirely from WebAppIntegrationTest. So instead of

> > > update all the tests to support it, we will write separate integration

> > > tests to cover the new cases and leave this flag off in the existing

> > > tests.

> > >

> > > BUG=b/319545692

> > >

> > > Change-Id: I260dc2aaa79a109e63f376ae8ac77fd6f6df3733

> > > Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5191337

> > > Commit-Queue: Maggie Cai

> > > Reviewed-by: Glen Robertson

> > > Reviewed-by: Daniel Murphy

> > > Code-Coverage: findit-for-me@appspot.gserviceaccount.com

> > > Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1247032}

> >

> > Bug: b/319545692

> > Change-Id: Ice84c869927617ce05303bac862cb6e5702c30eb

> > Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5202611

entry.title: [ARC] Run different script to cater FilesNewDirectoryTree flag
entry.content:
FilesNewDirectoryTree flag in Files app rewrites the whole directory

tree, which makes some query selectors (e.g. class name) used in ARC

deprecated, in order to make sure the Javascript used by ARC works

regardless of whether the flag is on or off, this CL introduces 2 sets

of scripts: one with existing selectors when the flag is off, one with

new selectors when the flag is on.

entry.title: Ignore unminimize-to-snapped if in transitional state
entry.content:
This CL makes CCState to ignore unminimize-to-snapped events if any

other snap event is still in progress (“transitional state”). Otherwise,

the window state would be overwritten during the transition phase.

For example, this case can happen when issuing a snap event to a

minimized window (whose pre-minimized state is snapped) and activating

the window before the client accepts the snap event because activating

minimized windows results in “restoring”. If the snap positions of the

pre-minimized state and the new snap event are different, the new

position should be respected.



BUG=b:318802862

BUG=b:322305794

TEST=ClientControlledStateTestClamshellAndTablet.SnapMinimizeAndUnminimize



Change-Id: Ibbb8f81a58de3838b95987cff2d07f488d67ab5c

entry.title: emoji_picker: Use DOM attributes instead of class names for variants
entry.content:
This should make the code slightly faster as Polymer does not need to do

string interpolation for CSS classes. In practice, this does not

noticeably affect emoji picker load speed.



This also cleans up the various `hasVariants` code, consolidating the

two implementations of checking whether an `EmojiVariants` has variants,

and removes the redundant "has variants" check in the template when we

know that a group has no variants.



A similar change was suggested in

https://crrev.com/c/3901656/comment/7ddac14e_8347b30c/.

entry.title: Reland "[URL] Carry over parsed.host correctly in canonicalizing url's host"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit f3ae9cad5b60b2ef99d117d298f916f21c29657c



The diff to the reveted CL is https://crrev.com/c/5247368/1..3



The reverted CL caused a DCHECK() error [1] inside the NDEBUG block of

the GURL sanitizer check. It is likely that the CQ try bots do not

include any debug bots by default.



I ran linux_chromium_dbg_ng in CQ try too this time.



Although I added a comment why we need to handle Component(0, 0)

specially, it's a bit complicated topic. I will revisit this when I

update url::Origin and other code to support empty hosts of

non-special URLs in a more robust manner.



- [1] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:url/gurl.cc;l=120





Original change's description:

> [URL] Carry over parsed.host correctly in canonicalizing url's host

>

> The current code incorrectly assigns an invalid Component ({0, -1}) to

> `out_host` during URL canonicalization, even when the input host is

> empty (e.g. {6, 0}). Fix that because the difference matters in

> non-special URLs.

>

> This is a blocking issue for https://crrev.com/c/5222760.

>

> Bug: 1416006

> Change-Id: I6894aa3af6819c70e5cc8feb8ba64ef3c52e00f3

entry.title: Revert "[exo] Trigger output activation notifications from wayland::Server"
entry.content:
This reverts commit d076b958a4ce4d3375f1b4b7cbbfe5ef9e4bb3ef.



Reason for revert: Linux ASan failures in `exo_unittests`



Original change's description:

> [exo] Trigger output activation notifications from wayland::Server

>

> Currently each instance of WaylandDisplayHandler (client-specific

> output handle in exo) maintains its own aura shell observation

> so that it can notify clients when the output it corresponds to

> has been activated.

>

> This CL moves the observation into exo::wayland::Server code and

> delegates to the appropriate WaylandDisplayOutput global wrapper

> where appropriate.

>

> This CL concludes the centralization of display-related

> observations into the Server class. The result is cleaner and easier

> to understand code.

>

> Follow up CLs will extract display-output related logic out of

> Server and into an independent class responsible for handling

> wayland output objects in exo, making new output extensions easier

> to implement and support.

>

> Note: Since output activation is now propagated from Server, the

> ActiveDisplay unittest has been moved into the aura shell server

> tests. This allows correct widget activation => client output event

> testing post refactor.

>

> Bug: 1518335

> Change-Id: I3d75d22eb043ac78c094880cb86bbd64b8a9858b

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5219895

> Reviewed-by: Mitsuru Oshima

> Commit-Queue: Thomas Lukaszewicz

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1254151}



Bug: 1518335

entry.title: Revert "[exo] Introduce OutputController to wayland::Server"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 0649147cf5be8859ab3bd70690c333c06cc465fa.



Reason for revert: Linux ASan failures in `OutputControllerTest.*`



Original change's description:

> [exo] Introduce OutputController to wayland::Server

>

> This is purely a refactor and no behavior changes are expected.

>

> This CL introduces a new OutputController class to wayland::Server.

> OutputController encapsulates the responsibility of managing the

> server-side view of wayland output objects.

>

> This includes

> - Initializing global output state during server startup

> - Keeping output state consistent with system Display state

> - Notifying wayland clients of output changes (metrics / activation)

>

> Adds a few tests. Follow up CLs will add more tests, adding a cleaner

> interface for the WaylandDisplayOutput class.

>

> Bug: 1518335

entry.title: snap-group: Reland SVOVS creation revamp
entry.content:
This cl relands changes in crrev.com/c/5242283 by fixing the

msan issue.



This cl completed the major revamp of the SVOVS creation by

focusing on the following items:

1. Don't bypass SVOVS creation in `WindowState::OnWMEvent()`;

2. Remove `auto_snap_controller_` owned by SVOVS as the instance

has been owned by `SplitViewController`, with this cl SVOVS can only

by created through `SplitViewController`;

3. Refresh snapped window bounds upon snap group creation and removal

by adjusting current API;

4. Unify handling when divider is created in clamshell in

`SplitViewDivider::RefreshSplitViewDividerInClamshell()`;

5. Further reduce the misusages of the feature flag;

6. Remove the !InSplitViewMode() in `SplitViewController` when it

doesn't make sense.



TODO:

- The snapped window bounds calculation differ between clamshell and

tablet split view with the existence of divider. This needs to be

unified, currently the calculation in snap group is correct;

- Re-enable the unit test when divider refactor work completes.



Fixed: b/321093825

Test: Update / fix existing tests + manual

entry.title: Make shallow clone work when clonable is true
entry.content:
This did not previously work correctly, but now, this will

work:



const shadow = host.attachShadow({mode:'open', clonable:true});

host.cloneNode(false);



The behavior is for the shadow root to be deep-cloned, even though

the `deep` argument to `cloneNode()` is `false`.



See this discussion for more context:

https://github.com/whatwg/dom/issues/1249



and this summary of the consensus:

https://github.com/whatwg/dom/issues/1249#issuecomment-1917772229



Bug: 1510466

entry.title: WebUI: Force initial render to be synchronous in CrLitElement.
entry.content:
Lit's default rendering logic after attaching an element to the DOM,

requires waiting for the `updateComplete` promise to resolve before

being able to access local Shadow DOM. This is a significant difference

compared to Polymer and accommodating would require exposing client code

to implementation details, updating multiple places in the code and is

likely to introduce regressions.



To address the above, an explicit call to `performUpdate()` is done in

CrLitElement's connectedCallback(), mimicking Polymer's behavior.

CrLitElement subclasses still use Lit's asynchronous rendering for

subsequent updates. Only the initial render is affected.



Also another disruptive difference that happens when a Lit element is nested within a Polymer dom-if (common pattern with cr-dialog) is

addressed similarly, by also explicitly calling performUpdate() within

the this.$ implementation.



While the changes above don't make Lit element's behave 100%

identically to Polymer, they do make migrations more seamless, by

having to make fewer (sometimes none) client code modifications.



Bug: 1503223

Change-Id: If4399c21f7096d05bac53a0af78dd5a5f3986707

entry.title: Discard invalid MP3 packets
entry.content:
Ffmpeg can sometimes return bad packets for MP3 stream containers (see

crbug.com/794782). We have had protection against such bad packets in

FfmpegDemuxer for a significant amount of time now, but no such

protection exists for AudioFileReader.



This CL fixes an issue with partially decoded mp3 files when using

AudioContext.decodeAudioData(). Discarding invalid MP3 packets prevents

decode errors, which reduce the length of the output.

This reverts commit a004972fae3b5061ca775d7cad6ef6abac813585.

> blink: optimizes Element::ClassChanged

> up to date (and not in the active document). In this case there is no

> additional processing needed (because ElementData is already up to date,

> and ClassChangedForElement() early outs if not in the active document).

entry.title: webview: try even harder to work around the resource problem.
entry.content:
The previously-landed workaround from

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/3339195

was only used on S+ devices and only if WebView initialization was

triggered from a background thread, but since this was implemented it's

become clear that this is not the only situation where the workaround

might help, and the risk of trying it is extremely low as we already

test if the resources *are* missing before trying to re-add them - so

if we don't try the workaround, we are almost guaranteed to crash

anyway, just a few lines later when we first need to access a resource.



So, just try the existing workaround on all OS versions, regardless of

which thread WebView init was launched from. This definitely won't solve

all possible cases here, but seems likely to help with some.

entry.title: [infra] Add edges to mixins wherever they are used.
entry.content:
Currently mixins specified in the config for a test within a basic suite

or on a test target itself do not have an edge created and are instead

just stored on a structure and copied into test_suites.pyl. This is in

contrast to their use in the matrix config in a matrix compound suite.

This CL changes it so that edges are created wherever a mixin is used

and those edges are used for generating the mixins and remove_mixins

fields. This prevents the currently possible situation where unused

tests can refer to non-existent mixins. Instead, all references to

mixins will be checked to exist when the starlark is run.

Since we are now reading heatmap data in ML service, we no longer need to send palm detection request from chromium side. Instead, we need to make a load service request when we initialize the device. As a result, we need to rework the APIs in HeatmapPalmDetector.

entry.title: Rename {absl => std}::optional in mojo generator.
entry.content:
Context:

--------

https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/cxx/c/nBD_1LaanTc/m/ghh-ZZhWAwAJ?utm_medium=email

As of https://crrev.com/1204351, absl::optional is now a type alias

for std::optional. We should migrate toward it.



This patch:

----------

This applies the rename to mojo/public/tools.



Script:

-------

```



cd mojo/public/tools

function replace {

echo "Replacing $1 by $2"

git grep -l "$1" \

| cut -f1 -d: \

| sort \

| uniq \

| xargs sed -i "s/$1/$2/g"

}

replace "absl::make_optional" "std::make_optional"

replace "absl::optional" "std::optional"

replace "absl::nullopt" "std::nullopt"

replace "absl::in_place" "std::in_place"

replace "absl::in_place_t" "std::in_place_t"

replace "\"third_party\/abseil-cpp\/absl\/types\/optional.h\"" ""



git cl format

```



Bug: chromium:1500249

entry.content:
This CL makes HTTPS-Upgrades (and HFM) not warn about HTTP navigations

to a site if they've previously visited that site via HTTP in the past

15 days (up from 7). Previously, it shared the duration with certificate

error bypasses -- since they're no longer the same, this CL introduces a

new variable for upgrading/HFM.

entry.title: Significantly enrich the mojom parser's AST generation
entry.content:
The major change is to introduce new AST node types to correspond to

significant grammar. Previously the parser would munge these into a

string or tuple of strings, only to be re-constituted as a different

type of AST node in the bindings generator. For example,

`pending_receiver` was parsed to `"rcv"`, whereas now it is an

`ast.Receiver(T)`.



Additionally, all AST nodes include full lexer state position tracking.

Previously only the line number was stored on AST nodes, but now the

full linespan and lexspan are stored. And because all significant

grammar now has a corresponding AST node, there is more position

information available throughout the AST.



Tested by building all targets that depend on the mojom bindings

and diffing the generated code.



Bug: 780263

Change-Id: Iac0c24c90408dd9f4f5c1aa27c8425d377143615

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5245874

entry.title: Record MajorVersion histogram on each load
entry.content:
The MajorVersion histogram for the Optimization Hints component is used

for automated regression testing during rollouts. It is currently

recorded only when a newer version of the component is loaded. Recording

the version each time the component is loaded will make it easier to

determine if the desired property of the system is upheld: that users

eventually end up with the latest version.



OBSOLETE_HISTOGRAM[OptimizationGuide.OptimizationHintsComponent.MajorVersion]=Replaced by OptimizationGuide.OptimizationHintsComponent.MajorVersion2

entry.title: media/gpu/ImageProcessorPerfTest JSON test results
entry.content:
Previous to this CL, the ImageProcessorPerf test results were written to

std::out. The test data was thus not able to be read via tools such as

Crosbolt.



Updates the ImageProcessorPerf test to have an option to specify an

output location to write the corresponding logs. If not specified, it

will output to the current directory.



Each ImageProcessorPerf test will output a json file corresponding to

the measured metrics of each test. These json files will be stored in

the specified output directory.



Bug: b:316160886

Test: Ran ImageProcessorPerfTest on Trogdor.

entry.title: shortcuts: Optimize a11y for shortcut app.
entry.content:
This CL improve a11y for shortcut app.

Main app page:

- Ensure accelerator-row is not tabbable, only the "Edit" button.

- Include a descriptive label for the "Edit" button for the row.

- e.g. "Edit button for Open notification"

- Enhance each row's aria-label to indicate its status.

- e.g. "Open notification, alt shift s, locked"

- Add an aria-label to the lock icon

- Add role="img" for icon, as recommended by the a11y review team.



Edit dialog:

- Fix the regression that the hint message and the key pressed won't

be announced during input.

- Announce the placeholder text before the hint mesasge

- e.g. "ctrl alt shift search plus key, Press 1-4 modifiers..."

- Provide detailed labels for "Edit" and "Delete" buttons for action.

- e.g. "Edit button for alt shift s".

- Add announcement when user add/edit/remove/restore shortcuts.

- e.g. "Shortcut deleted", "Shortcut restored".



Test: browser_tests && DUT

Bug: b/216049298

entry.title: [ Extensions ] Fix tabGroups.Move bug with adjacent groups
entry.content:
Fixes a bug that prevents extensions from moving a tab group to the right of another one due to an off by one error.



Fixing this caused a few other call sites to fail since they had implemented similar work-arounds.



The current way we calculate the index to move a tab group is by pretending the group and all of its tabs have been removed from the Tabstrip. The left over tabs represent the available indices we could move the group to (except for indices in the middle of another group).



Because there was an off by one error in the tab group extensions API and the case (moving a group to the right of another group) was unhandled in the TabstripModel, this has gone mostly unnoticed since their effects canceled each other out in most cases.



Regression tests are added in tab_groups_api_unittest for this scenario.



Change-Id: I92d8350157ab2ff23a6970bb5fe0ce4c15f5e881

Bug: 1417493

entry.title: Use valid paths in sandbox policy fuzzer
entry.content:
This fuzzer is not able to make progress as it is not properly

configuring the config. This has been a latent bug for some

time as the fuzzer has not been running. The issue was introduced

when AllowNamedPipes was removed from the sandbox,

so the fake rules added in the fuzzer test were modified to

pretend to be file rules, and the fuzzer wasn't tested, and didn't

run since https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5008918 was committed in

November.



This CL updates the paths provided to AllowFileAccess() to pass

the !IsReparsePoint() test when adding the rule. Fuzzer

setup also gains a bunch of CHECKs to ensure the setup

works and make it clear if something isn't ready before

attempting fuzzing.





A basic test case now passes:



```

sandbox_policy_rule_fuzzer.exe-5935798332882944

INFO: Running with entropic power schedule (0xFF, 100).

INFO: Seed: 984998772

INFO: Loaded 1 modules (15431 inline 8-bit counters): 15431 [00007FF6C9F6A888, 00007FF6C9F6E4CF),

Running: clusterfuzz-testcase-minimized-sandbox_policy_rule_fuzzer.exe-5935798332882944

***

*** NOTE: fuzzing was not performed, you have only

*** executed the target code on a fixed set of inputs.

***

```

entry.title: Fix TestViewsExamplesLaunches when Fluent scrollbars are enabled
entry.content:
When Fluent scrollbars are enabled, the call to NativeTheme instantiates

NativeThemeFluent, which calls skia::DefaultFontMgr() in its

constructor.

Later, gfx::InitializeFonts() gets called in ExamplesMainProc, which

expects the font manager to not be initialized and crashes.

This CL initializes fonts when Fluent scrollbars are enabled before the

NativeTheme gets instantiated to avoid crashing the test.

entry.title: webauthn: make enclave errors fatal to the request
entry.content:
Similar to hybrid authenticators, if something goes wrong with an

enclave request we should flag it to the user and end the request. We

don't have the UI wired up for this yet, but this change makes the

infrastructure changes.
